node.title: Un desconocido parecía mi gemelo. Ese fue solo el comienzo
node.description: Un correo electrónico reveló un viejo secreto de mi familia, luego tuve que aprender a vivir con eso.

node.title: Jil Sander Ski Wear, Coming to a City Block Near You
node.description: Fashion’s reigning minimalists collaborate with Arc’teryx, the outerwear brand favored by hikers and hypebeasts.

node.title: The Emily Ratajkowski You’ll Never See
node.description: With her new book, the model tries to escape the oppressions of the male gaze. So our writer is keeping some of her secrets.

node.title: Is the Supreme Court on Its Way to Becoming a Conservative Bastion?
node.description: Linda Greenhouse’s “Justice on the Brink” looks back at the Supreme Court’s last year, with intimations of what we can expect in the future.

node.title: A U.F.C. Champion’s Title Is Not Enough. He Wants to Fight a Boxer Next.
node.description: Kamaru Usman, the U.F.C.’s top pound-for-pound fighter, is trying to generate buzz for a fight with the boxing champion Saúl Álvarez. It’s not likely to work.

node.title: Dolphins and Texans Swap Turnovers, if Not a Quarterback
node.description: The teams, both winless since Week 1 and connected by trade speculation surrounding Texans quarterback Deshaun Watson, combined for nine turnovers.

node.title: What We Learned From Week 9 in the N.F.L.
node.description: Baker Mayfield took control of a Browns team that looked ready to collapse. The Packers got their first long look at Jordan Love, and Dak Prescott and Josh Allen struggled in shocking upsets.

node.title: What It Was Like to Run the Marathon
node.description: You could sense the smaller field of runners, but there’s nothing like having thousands of strangers cheer for you.

node.title: Inspired to run a marathon? Here’s how to start training for it.
node.description: Whether you’re looking to start running for the first time, or to improve your marathon time, try our New York Times guides to running.

node.title: Scientists Fight a New Source of Vaccine Misinformation: Aaron Rodgers
node.description: The Green Bay Packers quarterback, one of the most visible athletes in the country, last week used anti-vaccination rhetoric as his reasoning for not getting vaccinated against Covid-19.

node.title: What Do You Want to Know About Kids and Vaccines?
node.description: The Times is hosting a live chat with a pediatric infectious disease specialist and two reporters about the coronavirus vaccine and children. We’d like to hear your questions.

node.title: Congress Is Investigating McKinsey Over Its Role in the Opioid Crisis
node.description: A House committee has requested documents related to the firm’s advice to drug makers and potential conflicts of interest with the F.D.A.

node.title: Michael Rutter, Pioneering Child Psychiatrist, Is Dead at 88
node.description: His wide-ranging research helped transform his field, a colleague said, by “insisting on using data to drive thinking about diagnosis and treatment.”

node.title: Stephen Karpiak, Pathbreaking H.I.V. Researcher, Dies at 74
node.description: His work helped change people’s attitude toward older people living with the virus that causes AIDS.

node.title: Rabbi Earl A. Grollman, 96, Dies; Sought to Demystify Death and Grief
node.description: He wrote prolifically about grief, counseled the bereaved after 9/11 and the Oklahoma City bombing and paid particular attention to children. “Grief is the price we pay for love,” he’d say.

node.title: To Build the Metaverse, Meta First Wants to Build Stores
node.description: The social networking company has discussed opening physical stores to showcase its virtual reality and augmented reality devices.

node.title: Crypto Is Cool. Now Get on the Yacht.
node.description: NFT.NYC, a gathering for nonfungible token enthusiasts, offered a taste of a crypto-filled future.

node.title: Google Temps Fought Loss of Pandemic Bonus. And Won.
node.description: When a Google staffing agency reneged on a promise to pay an attendance bonus, temps who are part of the company’s union organized and forced it to backtrack.

node.title: Behind Elon Musk’s Twitter Poll Is a Tax Bill Coming Due
node.description: He asked whether he should sell 10 percent of his stock, and Twitter voters said yes. Stock options he was granted in 2012 are “a ticking tax time bomb,” one expert said.

node.title: The Popularity of E-Bikes Isn’t Slowing Down
node.description: Motorized bicycles are outselling all-electric cars and have the potential to transform urban transit.

node.title: Rivian prices its I.P.O., valuing the electric-vehicle maker at nearly $70 billion.
node.description: The company, backed by Amazon and Ford, has delivered only 156 trucks so far, but its market worth approaches that of Ford.

node.title: A Quiet Studio With a Home-Court Advantage
node.description: Tim Burns, who trains basketball players, including N.B.A. pros, found a studio in Brooklyn for $3,150. His favorite amenity: the basketball court.

node.title: Over 100,000 New York City public school students were homeless last year, data show.
node.description: An urgent crisis awaits the incoming mayor, Eric Adams, in January.

node.title: Elaine Romagnoli, Longtime Fixture of Lesbian Nightlife, Dies at 79
node.description: The bustling downtown bars that Ms. Romagnoli created, beginning in 1972, became central to New York City’s gay community.

node.title: A Chip Shop That’s Not a Chip Shop: Dame, in the Village
node.description: With exceptional fish and chips, the chef Ed Szymanski turned a pandemic pop-up into a postpandemic destination.

node.title: N.Y.’s governor promises grants for employers and laid-off workers in the ailing tourism industry.
node.description: Ms. Hochul said the state would make payments of $2,750 to as many as 36,000 workers who lost jobs during the pandemic as part of a $450 million package to help the tourism industry.

node.title: Protesters Gather Outside Missouri Fraternity After University Suspends Greek Activities
node.description: "Hazing has gone on for too long, and it shouldn't take someone almost dying for the university to do something about it," student Olivia Sommer said.

node.title: Teacher on Leave After 'War Hooping, Tomahawk Chopping' Dance in Math Class Sparks Outrage
node.description: The video was filmed by a Native American student who reportedly "felt that violence was being committed against him."

node.title: Mom Sparks Backlash for Telling Child It's 'Her Own Fault' She Missed Out on Dream College
node.description: The Redditor reportedly told her daughter that "every assignment [she] never turned in is a dollar [she] p**sed away."

node.title: Ohio High School Cancels Performance of 'She Kills Monsters' Over Implied Gay Character
node.description: The play is among the most popular modern productions for high schools and the version planned had been retooled for young audiences.

node.title: Lawsuit Alleges Professor Was Fired for Criticizing Mike Pence: 'Little Demon Mouth'
node.description: Lora Burnett alleges her termination violated her First Amendment rights because it came after she posted on Twitter that Pence was a "scumbag."

node.title: Student Wears KKK Halloween Costume Through 4 Class Periods Before Being Reprimanded
node.description: "We are committed to addressing what has occurred and working with this student to help him recognize the harm his actions have caused," the school's principal said.

node.title: Elementary Class' Field Trip to Bar Prompts Death Threats Toward School Board
node.description: The owner of the bar and grill told local media outlets he too has received "horrible" emails in response to the students' visit.

node.title: North Carolina Parents 'Shocked' by Middle School Art Assignment Depicting a Sexual Act
node.description: "I didn't think I needed to look up what my child was learning in an art class," said one school parent of the art assignment.

node.title: Florida 'Teacher of the Year' Allegedly Hit Student in the Face, Arrested for Child Abuse
node.description: The incident occurred after a student commented on an Instagram post announcing the teacher's award, but the teacher has denied touching the student.

node.title: Teacher Who Came to School in Blackface Forced to Wash to 'Not Cause Further Harm'
node.description: "There must be accountability when racism is exhibited and our children are harmed," an advocacy group said.

node.title: University of Florida Under Review After Refusing to Let 3 Professors Testify in Court
node.description: The school previously said that the testimony would go against the school's interest and relationship with Gov. Ron DeSantis.

node.title: Law School to Remove Name of Founder Who Sponsored Massacres of Native Americans
node.description: The University of California Hastings College of the Law voted to change its name to distance itself from its founder's attacks against Indigenous people

node.title: California College to Allow Homeless Students to Sleep in Their Cars in Secure Garage
node.description: "Our goal at LBCC is always to remove barriers that get in the way of our student's success," interim superintendent of the LBCC District, Dr. Mike Muñoz said.

node.title: 'Party of Parents': GOP to Build on Fight Against Critical Race Theory for Midterms
node.description: Republicans are planning to strengthen their campaigns against diversity-centered academia in the wake of Tuesday's elections.

node.title: Multiple Yale University Buildings Threatened With Bombs
node.description: The threats had targeted at least seven facilities across the Yale campus in New Haven, Connecticut.

node.title: Death Science Says It Had a Contract to Use Vet's Body for Education After Widow's Dispute
node.description: An organization that purchased a cadaver for what it said was educational purposes, used it for public dissection at an event where tickets were sold.

node.title: Indiana School District Sued Over Transgender Restroom Access, Use of Wrong Names
node.description: "The refusal to allow a student to use the correct restroom can be extremely damaging," ACLU of Indiana legal director Ken Falk said.

node.title: Internet Calls Woman Out After Eating MIL's Birthday Cake in Viral Post
node.description: The woman told her husband he was overreacting after he was upset that she stole a slice of his mother's birthday cake.

node.title: Weed Helped Man Who Hated Exercise Become Ultra-Marathon Runner
node.description: In his new book "Runner's High," Josiah Hesse delves into the subculture of amateur and elite athletes who use cannabis for exercise.

node.title: Mom of Five Dies Before Meeting Newborn After Waiting To Get COVID Vaccine
node.description: Saiqa Parveen's husband said: "I'm going to pass this message to the whole world, I just beg all people to get the vaccine."

node.title: Most Russians Return to Work as Just 5 Regions Extend Non-Working Period
node.description: COVID-19 cases and deaths across Russia remain high as the country's coronavirus task force reported 39,400 infections and 1,190 deaths on Monday.

node.title: Airlines in U.S., U.K. Increasing Flights as Travel Rules Ease for International Residents
node.description: Flights between the U.S. and U.K. alone are projected to increase 21 percent this month, according to a travel analytics firm.

node.title: Elementary Schools Urged by White House to Set up COVID Vaccine Clinics for Students
node.description: The Food and Drug Administration says the shots are safe and proven to be almost 91 percent effective in preventing COVID-19 in a study of 2,268 children.

node.title: 25 Kids at Afghan Hospital Died of Malnutrition in 2 Months, Staff Working Without Pay
node.description: Afghanistan has seen a huge surge in children's malnutrition cases because of drought and the worsening economic crisis under Taliban rule.

node.title: Railroads Offering Employees $300 to Get Vaccinated as Sides Argue About Federal Mandate
node.description: BNSF railroad filed a lawsuit Sunday against its major unions, joining Norfolk Southern and Union Pacific, both of which filed suits last month.

node.title: Woman Says She Almost Lost Her Leg After Spin Class in Video Viewed 3M Times
node.description: The TikToker suffered from rhabdomyolysis, a condition that has become associated with spin classes and other forms of strenuous exercise.

node.title: Some Pro Sports Teams Nix COVID Vaccinations, Negative Test Requirements For Fans
node.description: The teams include a mix of NHL and NBA clubs from Tennessee to Texas.

node.title: NFL Has a Bizarre Week, and This Week's Games Are Only Just Beginning
node.description: From COVID to injuries, a trade whiff, a fatal car crash and more, this weekend's games couldn't get here fast enough.

node.title: New York City Marathon Set to Return With a Variety of Pandemic-Forced Changes
node.description: The 33,000 runners are expected to be vaccinated or show proof of a negative COVID-19 test within 48 hours.

node.title: NFL, Washington Football Team Should Lift Sexual Harassment Claim NDAs, Congress Says
node.description: More than a year ago, 15 former employees of the Washington Football Team made allegations of sexual harassment within the organization.

node.title: NASCAR Denounces 'Let's Go Brandon' Chant, Will Sue for Use of Slogan With Its Trademarks
node.description: The "Let's Go Brandon" chant originated at a NASCAR race and has been used to criticize President Joe Biden.

node.title: Shalane Flanagan Returns to NYC Marathon 4 Years After Historic Win With New Goal in Sight
node.description: The former NYC Marathon champion will attempt to complete her sixth marathon in six weeks during Sunday's race.

node.title: Terry Bradshaw Rips Aaron Rodgers Over COVID Fiasco: 'You Lied to Everyone'
node.description: "Unfortunately, we've got players that pretty much think only about themselves," the Pittsburgh Steelers legend said.

node.title: Simone Biles Taking Break From Gymnastics to Figure Out 'What I Really Want to Do'
node.description: "For me, it's just finding out what I really want to do," Biles said, adding that she is not sure whether the break will be temporary or permanent.

node.title: Athlete Welfare, Giving More Governing Power to Schools Among NCAA Restructuring Goals
node.description: The new constitution is the first phase of transforming the NCAA to give more power to schools and conferences, instead of the Indianapolis-based association.

node.title: Female Hockey Goalie Who Was Victim of Vulgar Chants From Students Returns to Ice
node.description: 50 to 60 students have been identified and punished for the incident, which occurred in Pennsylvania.

node.title: Oscar Pistorius Required to Meet With Victim's Parents to Be Considered for Parole
node.description: The South African Olympian fatally shot his girlfriend, Reva Steenkamp, on Valentine's Day 2013 and was convicted of murder in 2015.

node.title: College Sports Paid Over $500M in 'Dead Money' to Fired Coaches Over Last Decade
node.description: Auburn, Nebraska, Texas, Ole Miss and Kansas were among the schools that paid coaches at least $20 million to not coach.

node.title: State Farm Cuts Back on Aaron Rodgers' Ads, Still Stands With QB Amid Vaccine Comments
node.description: Less than 2 percent of State Farm advertisements featured Rodgers on Sunday, down significantly from 25 percent one week earlier.

node.title: Washington Benches Head Coach As 'No Tolerance' Response to Sideline Skirmish With Player
node.description: Washington head coach Jimmy Lake was suspended from team activities for the week and Saturday's game against Arizona State after pushing player Ruperake Fuavai.

node.title: NBA Champion Bucks Visit Biden's White House, Ending Drought From the Trump Era
node.description: President Joe Biden welcomed the champions into the White House, the first team in nearly five years.

node.title: Ancient Earth Hit by Rain Storms 100s of Miles Wide Due to Extreme Heat
node.description: Scientists compared periods of punishing rains and withering droughts in Earth's hothouse epochs to a giant atmospheric "battery" recharging then unleashing powerful storms.

node.title: Revolutionary War Battle Plan Features Early Usage of Term 'United States of America'
node.description: The document, which was created by Continental Army Major Moses Ashley in 1780, had been lost for generations.

node.title: Bear Caught Trying To Hibernate Under Family Home in Colorado
node.description: "We've had bears wander through before, but none settling in," resident Michael Payne said.

node.title: Man and Teenager Killed by Falling Tree Branches as Storm Batters Portland
node.description: The fourteen-year-old's aunt paid tribute to him saying "sweet, just a smiling, wonderful child who believed in volunteerism."

node.title: Elon Musk's Twitter Antics Prompt Launch of Risky Lorde Edge, Abide(N) Crypto Coins
node.description: Several new tokens appear to have been inspired by the SpaceX CEO's Twitter activity over the past two days, but people should be cautious about investing.

node.title: Rare 'Cotton Candy' Lobster Found Off Maine in 1 in 100 Million Catch
node.description: The lobster's unusual color is likely the result of a genetic mutation.

node.title: U.S. Lags in Policing Big Tech Due to Companies Being Homegrown, Expert Says
node.description: Companies are likely arguing to Washington officials that tighter rules would give them a disadvantage as they compete with other companies, an expert said.

node.title: Iceland Sets up World's Largest Air-Scrubbing Machines, but Environmental Impact Is Unclear
node.description: "We have already failed on climate to the extent to which direct air capture is one of the many things we must do," said a senior researcher.

node.title: Rand Paul Says Cryptocurrency Could Replace Dollar
node.description: The Kentucky senator said "government currencies are so unreliable" and aren't "backed by anything."

node.title: TikTok Denies Sharing User Information With China Amid Concerns About Safety of U.S. Data
node.description: "We do not share information with the Chinese government," said the head of TikTok's public policy for the Americas during a Senate hearing.

node.title: L.A. Will Start Fining Shipping Companies Lingering at Marine Terminals Amid Supply Crisis
node.description: The policy will go into effect on November 1, with fines accruing each day per container.

node.title: Big Oil to Testify on Climate Change Disinformation—What This Could Mean for Green Economy
node.description: The world's largest oil companies will answer questions before Congress on their alleged efforts to obscure the role of fossil fuels in global warming.

node.title: Supply Issues, Rising Prices Won't Deter Holiday Shoppers From Spending Big: Trade Group
node.description: The National Retail Federation predicts that sales in November and December will grow between 8.5 percent and 10.5 percent.

node.title: 3 New York Starbucks Stores to Vote on Unionizing, Would Be First in U.S. If Measure Passes
node.description: "It's been disappointing to see Starbucks working overtime to try to stop us from organizing, but today's decision is a big win...," Michele Eisen said.

node.title: France Suggests It Might Cut U.K. Energy Supplies Amid Dispute Over Fishing Rights
node.description: France has also threatened to block British boats from docking at its ports if more French boats aren't granted licenses to fish in U.K. waters by Tuesday.

node.title: 47 Percent of Americans Expect the Economy to Worsen, 33 Percent Think It's in Good Shape
node.description: Americans beliefs toward economic growth under the Biden administration have taken a sharp turn since the beginning of the year.

node.title: American Airlines Cancels Over 350 Flights, 4th Day of Woes Due to Staff Shortage
node.description: American Airlines saw a fourth day of challenges due to staff shortages that have led to the cancellation of hundreds more flights.

node.title: Hertz Says It's Buying 100,000 Teslas, But Elon Musk Tweets 'No Contract Signed'
node.description: "Tesla has far more demand than production, therefore we will only sell cars to Hertz for the same margin as to consumers," Elon Musk tweeted.

node.title: Internet Overwhelmingly Supports Man Who Fired Employee Over 'Pattern' of Lateness
node.description: The highly-relatable issue sparked a viral conversation on Reddit, racking up thousands of comments.

node.title: Joe Manchin, Kyrsten Sinema, Know What Happened to Pols Who Did What They're Doing
node.description: It pays to oppose popular progressive programs: Big Business says yes to Democratic lawmakers who say no.

node.title: L.A. Businesses Could Be Fined Up to $5K if They Don't Enforce City's COVID Vaccine Mandate
node.description: The mandate will begin to be imposed on November 29. After the first offense warning, subsequent warnings could result in fines.

node.title: Tesla Stock Prices Dip After Elon Musk Proposes Selling 10 Percent of His Own Shares
node.description: The billionaire said the only way he can pay taxes is to sell Tesla stocks because he does not take a cash salary.

node.title: Pandemic Recession Has Been More Harmful to Women, Fed Chair Says
node.description: The pandemic has taken a heavier toll on women with children, causing many to quit the workforce, leaving economists to speculate if a return is in sight.

node.title: Remington Moving Headquarters From New York to Gun-Friendly Georgia, Will Invest $100M
node.description: "Georgia's firearms industry is responsible for thousands of jobs and millions of dollars of investment in our communities," Georgia Governor Brian Kemp said.

node.title: Just 12 Percent of Calls to Virginia Employment Commission Are Answered, New Report Says
node.description: "It's clear that additional oversight and assistance is needed," Joint Legislative Audit and Review Commission leader Lauren Axselle said.

node.title: 'Presidents Are Not Kings': Judge Says Trump Can't Claim Executive Privilege
node.description: Chutkan's decision rested largely on laws and court arguments made after the Watergate scandal of Republican President Richard Nixon.

node.title: A poll, a putsch and a pandemic. One unexpected year reporting from the US
node.description: Returning home from 12 months in Washington, Greg Jennett reflects on the big stories and the United States' constant capacity to surprise.

node.title: Katherine close contacts to be re-tested, residents urged to monitor health after wastewater samples test positive for COVID
node.description: COVID viral fragments have been detected in wastewater in the Northern Territory town of Katherine, prompting health authorities to ask residents to monitor their health for any symptoms.

node.title: Lion takeover of Stone & Wood would 'free up' taps for independent brewers, ACCC says
node.description: The nation's competition regulator says it won't oppose Lion's proposed acquisition of Fermentum, owner of Byron Bay-based Stone & Wood.

node.title: 'Allowing a coup to be staged': Prince Harry says he warned Twitter CEO about deadly assault on US Capitol
node.description: Prince Harry says he warned Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey via email that "his platform was allowing a coup to be staged" a day before the deadly assault on the US Capitol.

node.title: Socceroos primed for emotional homecoming
node.description: Socceroos boss Graham Arnold says he's seen a lot of emotion in his players ahead of playing on home soil for the first time in 763 days.

node.title: 'Zoe's Law' introduced to NSW Parliament 12 years after Brodie lost unborn baby to drunk driver
node.description: A bill first proposed after a drunk driver hit Brodie Donegan, causing the loss of her foetus, Zoe, 12 years ago, is introduced to NSW Parliament in a bid to impose harsher penalties for crimes that result in the loss of an unborn baby.

node.title: 'A big deal': Donald Trump fails in bid to block probe into attack on US Capitol
node.description: Federal Judge Tanya Chutkan rejects an argument by Mr Trump's lawyers that White House telephone records, visitor logs and other documents should be hidden from a US House of Representatives committee investigating the January 6 riot.
